articles.headline: Low Light Becomes a Highlight
articles.snippet: New cameras from Sony and Fujifilm come with redesigned sensors that mark an important step forward in personal photography.
articles.abstract: New cameras from Sony and Fujifilm come with redesigned sensors that mark an important step forward in personal photography.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years now, the world’s camera companies have been taking the public for a ride. They’ve taught us to believe that what makes one camera better than another is the number of megapixels it has  when, in fact, the number of tiny colored dots making up a photo has very little to do with its color, clarity or even detail.

articles.headline: Dealers Reassured on Clunker Rebates
articles.snippet: Some auto dealers have stopped taking part because their reimbursement requests have not yet been approved, leading to cash problems at their businesses.
articles.abstract: Some auto dealers have stopped taking part because their reimbursement requests have not yet been approved, leading to cash problems at their businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The government’s “cash for clunkers” program is proving to be so painful and such a financial burden for auto dealers that some have stopped taking part, despite its early popularity and success.
articles.byline: By Nick Bunkley and Jack Healy

articles.headline: Toyota, Hybrid Innovator, Holds Back in Race to Go Electric
articles.snippet: Mitsubishi and Nissan hope to leapfrog Toyota and G.M. by focusing on battery-powered cars rather than hybrids like the Prius and the Volt.
articles.abstract: Mitsubishi and Nissan hope to leapfrog Toyota and G.M. by focusing on battery-powered cars rather than hybrids like the Prius and the Volt.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Despite Toyota’s image as the world’s greenest automaker, the company that brought us the Prius  totem of the environmentally conscious  has fallen behind in the race for the all-electric car.

articles.headline: A Lawsuit Tries to Get at Hackers Through the Banks They Attack
articles.snippet: A volunteer group called Unspam Technologies hopes that knowing more about data thefts and victims will help improve security.
articles.abstract: A volunteer group called Unspam Technologies hopes that knowing more about data thefts and victims will help improve security.
articles.lead_paragraph: A lawsuit filed on Wednesday against some of the most shadowy Internet criminals  gangs based in Eastern Europe that electronically break into business computers, steal banking passwords and transfer themselves money  is being used to pry information from a group that is nearly as reclusive as the hackers: banks whose computers have been compromised.

articles.headline: Countrywide Loses Ruling in Loan Suit
articles.snippet: The ruling was a win for holders of mortgage-backed securities who sued Countrywide after it agreed to modify thousands of loans.
articles.abstract: The ruling was a win for holders of mortgage-backed securities who sued Countrywide after it agreed to modify thousands of loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan has rejected an argument by Countrywide Financial seeking certain protections from investor lawsuits under new legislation intended to encourage modifications of home loans.

articles.headline: C.I.A. Sought Blackwater’s Help to Kill Jihadists
articles.snippet: Contractors were hired as part of a secret program to assassinate top Al Qaeda operatives, officials said.
articles.abstract: Contractors were hired as part of a secret program to assassinate top Al Qaeda operatives, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Central Intelligence Agency in 2004 hired outside contractors from the private security contractor Blackwater USA as part of a secret program to locate and assassinate top operatives of Al Qaeda, according to current and former government officials.

articles.headline: Bernanke, a Hero to His Own, Can't Shake Critics
articles.snippet: Despite his credibility in financial circles, the Federal Reserve chairman has come under fire from lawmakers.
articles.abstract: Despite his credibility in financial circles, the Federal Reserve chairman has come under fire from lawmakers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, no longer looks sleep-deprived.

articles.headline: Afghan Election Called a Success Despite Attacks
articles.snippet: Rocket attacks and Taliban intimidation suppressed turnout, but enough voters cast ballots that officials said they had thwarted efforts by the insurgents to derail the vote.
articles.abstract: Rocket attacks and Taliban intimidation suppressed turnout, but enough voters cast ballots that officials said they had thwarted efforts by the insurgents to derail the vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Scattered rocket attacks and Taliban intimidation suppressed turnout in Afghanistan’s presidential election Thursday. But enough voters cast ballots that Afghan officials said they had thwarted efforts by the insurgents to derail the vote.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Stephen Farrell

articles.headline: Bombs Hurt Maliki Case That Iraq Can Guard Itself
articles.snippet: Recent attacks undercut Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s case that Iraq is ready to defend itself and deepened a widespread dissatisfaction with him.
articles.abstract: Recent attacks undercut Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s case that Iraq is ready to defend itself and deepened a widespread dissatisfaction with him.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  In recent months, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki has sought to convince Iraq that it is finished with war. He ordered blast walls around Baghdad pulled down, including those near the Foreign and Finance Ministries. He has refused to ask the American military for help in any major way since Iraqi soldiers took full security responsibility in the cities on June 30.
